item.title: visualizing.org
item.description: Visualizing.org looks like an exciting new community devoted to information design and sensemaking--making sense of complex issues through data and design. An excerpt from their about page describes the site: It's a place to showcase work, get feedback, ensure that your work is seen by lots of people and gets used by teachers, journalists, and conference organizers to help educate the public about various world issues. Visualizing is also a free resource to search for data.

item.title: WTF is HTML5 (Infographic)
item.description: I found this graph explaining HTML 5 features via @obxdesignworks. Succinctly describes the major features enabled by HTML 5 that you need to be aware of: Canvas and video elements, offline storage and geolocation. The graph below shows a snapshot of current support and intent to support in web browsers. Shows that IE is well behind the field in terms of readiness as we speak, but IE 9 intends to support.

item.title: BBC News: The top 100 sites on the internet
item.description: The BBC charts the top 100 Internet sites in terms of traffic (unique visits) using January 2010 data from Nielsen. Data covers the UK, France, Germany, Italy, Spain, Switzerland, Brazil, US and Australia. The categories - such as retail, social networks, search/portal - were defined by the BBC. The maps were produced using the Prefuse Flare software, developed by the University of California Berkeley. You can mouse over the squares to see site names.

item.title: Save the kittens...
item.description: Mark Goetz makes a plea to save the baby kittens. Because every time you make a powerpoint, Edward Tufte kills a kitten... and David Byrne does a happy dance. I love how the cats run off the side of the canvas. Oh, and how no one in that meeting is paying attention... Awesome. http://markandrewgoetz.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2009/11/tufte-wallpaper.png

item.title: InfoGraphic Designs: Overview, Examples and Best Practices
item.description: Anders Ross provides a definition, brief history, and best practices for designing infographics followed by a huge number of example screenshots. View them all at Infoshift. http://www.instantshift.com/2009/06/07/infographic-designs-overview-examples-and-best-practices/

item.title: Concept Maps
item.description: Hugh Dubberly of ddo does some nice concept maps, poster-sized infographics to model ideas. Their description: We create concept maps, a type of model, to explore and learn about complex information spaces. By showing everything—the forest and the trees—in a single view, concept maps help people create mental models and clarify thoughts. We create concept maps to share understanding—with our clients, peers, and others interested in the subjects. Their gallery of downloadable PDF posters include the creative process, play, innovation, and much more.

item.title: Feltron 2008 Annual Report
item.description: Nick Felton's annual report continues to take mundane data and meticulously render superb stastical diagrams and information graphics. If every corporate Power Point chart looked this good, fewer people would be bored out of their skulls in meetings. http://feltron.com/index.php?/content/2008_annual_report/

item.title: The Browser Wars
item.description: Cool infographic from Pixel Labs depicting the Browser wars, based on W3 Schools Browser Stats. Reminds me of the "Napoleon's March" graphic in Tufte's book. http://www.pixellabs.com/images/browserwars.png
